Award.AwardTitle: SI2-SSE: The Next Generation of the Montage Mosaic Engine

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Images produced by the new generation of astronomical instruments are addressing fundamental questions about the Universe, such as the formation of the very first galaxies after the Big Bang, and the very first stages of the formation of stars in massive dust clouds in our Galaxy. Exploiting this new generation of data is difficult because the data sets they produce are sufficiently complex and large as to demand new approaches to data processing that lag far behind developments in instrumentation. A growing community is working to rectify this state-of-affairs. This project will deliver software tools that will aggregate data from the new instruments into images of large scale regions of the sky so that astronomers can fully study scientific questions such as those identified above. This approach of studying aggregated images, or mosaics, is a powerful tool in astronomy. The project will deliver the next generation of an existing mosaic-building engine, Montage, which is in wide use in astronomy and in educational activities. It will support processing of the new data sets such that they can be visualized in immersive tools such as the World Wide Telescope, widely used in developing innovative approaches to education, and such that that they can generate data used by Citizen Science services such as Zooniverse. Montage will come be bundled with a set of tools that will enable astronomers to process massive collections images on powerful "cloud computing" platforms. These tools will be applicable to many data-intensive problems in fields such as earthquake prediction, DNA sequencing, and climate modeling. Finally, Montage is in wide use in developing and testing national cyberinfrastructure to benefit the U.S. science community. We anticipate that the next-generation Montage will be used in the same way to develop ever more powerful cyberinfrastructure as data volumes grow rapidly in all fields.

In greater detail, the project will deliver the next generation of the Montage image mosaic engine, which will offer new capabilities that respond to the changing astronomy data and computing landscapes. These capabilities, requested by the user community, are: 1. Support for mosaicking of data cubes, now routinely generated by modern instrumentation; 2. Support for two widely used sky-partitioning schemes, HEALPix and TOAST; 3. An API to enable users to call Montage directly in Python and other languages. The work to develop memory management and subsetting techniques to support mosaicking will be available for others to use and extend. Support for HEALPix will enable integration and analysis of far-infrared, cosmic background data sets with other image data sets. TOAST will enable essentially any image data set to be incorporated into the WWT. Montage will be bundled with a turnkey package of open source tools that provision resources and run applications on cloud platforms. This package will build on knowledge gained in creating data products at scale with cloud platforms. These tools will bring cloud computing to scientists who have little system configuration knowledge, one of the biggest barriers to entry; these tools are general purpose and will be applicable to data intensive applications in may fields. Thus Montage will provide powerful new capabilities to astronomers, to projects analyzing data at scale to create new data products, and to scientists in data-intensive fields outside astronomy. The next-generation toolkit will inherit the sustainable Montage architecture, which has attracted a large user base among astronomers, E/PO specialists, and computer technologists. Montage is written in C, is portable across all common Unix platforms, highly scalable and delivered as components that are easy to incorporate into pipelines and processing environments. Montage is the only mosaic engine with all these characteristics. The project will use the evolutionary delivery lifecycle model. The code will be a made accessible on the GitHub repository, and released as Open Source code with a BSD 3-clause license. A Users' Panel will advise on detailed specifications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The development of complex instruments, extremely large telescopes, and high-performance computers are powering the accelerating growth of large and ever more complex astronomy data sets. Whereas image data were once represented in two-dimensional form, similar to the kind of images created by commercial digital cameras, they are now often represented in three-dimensional form, with the third dimension representing a series of data in time or wavelength. Moreover, the way in which images represent the sky has evolved considerably. Images are now often organized as sets of tiles or cells of the sky, to promote efficient computational analysis or to permit display in immersive visualization environments such as the World Wide Telescope.  In response, we have, with this award, delivered software tools that enable the astronomy community to process these modern images and aggregate them into wide-area mosaics of the sky, and to visualize and manage these mosaics. 


Building mosaics is essential in modern astronomy because structures in the sky are much bigger than the individual images acquired by telescopes and satellites. Thus, astronomers can now create large-scale three-dimensional images acquired by instruments operating across the electromagnetic spectrum. They can transform images organized for analysis of data, such as those generated by projects that study the background radiation left over from the Big Bang and faint emission from dust grains in our Galaxy, into forms suitable for visualization and for aggregation with other data sets. And, they can represent images in a form that can be consumed by the World Wide Telescope.

The new tools have been incorporated into a toolkit called Montage, which was first developed in the early 2000's to support the generation of mosaics using the two-dimensional images prevalent then. The toolkit is freely available with an "Open Source" license that allows anyone to use, update, and redistribute the code. Astronomers have taken advantage of the new features and the availability of the code to perform research. During this award, 95 peer-reviewed papers have cited Montage as one of the tools used. 


The impact of Montage goes beyond astronomical research. Because it has been designed as a set of tools rather than as a large, single application, software environments can integrate Montage to support the creation of new data products for the research community. To date, 27 projects have applied Montage in this way, and they have often had a wide impact in astronomy. These applications include data processing by newly operating instruments such as the Dark Energy Survey camera; support for research proposal planning for the James Webb Space Telescope, scheduled for launch in June 2019; and discovery of 86 near-Earth asteroids by the Lincoln Labs Asteroids Search Program.

The toolkit design enables Montage to run on many high-performance computers, including computing clouds and large clusters of machines, and as such has proven compelling to the computer science community. They have used Montage as a real-world application for developing next-generation computing infrastructure that will be used to support data-intensive processing in the U.S. across many disciplines. This infrastructure includes tools for massive computing on clouds, schedulers for running  complex jobs on high-performance computers, and data orchestration systems that can  recover from processing and hardware failures. The impact is such that over the period of this award, 421 computer science publications and 8 computer science PhD theses cite Montage as a cornerstone in developing the advances reported.


Montage is recognized as an example of sustainable software, and so the team has, by invitation, been active in national, multi-disciplinary debates on the issues of software transparency and sustainability, and the related issue of verification of published results. These debates, which are taking place across all disciplines, recognize the role played by software in modern research and the need to foster efficiency in software development and transparency in evaluating research claims. The Montage team has helped organize meetings on topics such as Licensing Astrophysics Codes, Best Practices for Software Releases, and Improving Software Citation and Credit, and have made presentations and taken part in panel discussions.


The toolkit design has been responsible for the sustainability and wide usage of Montage, which will continue to be developed for the benefit of research communities as their needs evolve.
